value.title: Copy Conditional Columns in Power Query or Power BI
value.excerpt: In this video, Adam looks at how to use conditional columns within Power Query and then copying them for use in other queries or Power BI Desktop files. This is a great technique if you don't want to retype all of the conditional items in the dialog in Power BI.  LET'S CONNECT!  Guy in a Cube -- https://guyinacube.com
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/OSoTyZVRqJk" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

images.title: Copy Conditional Columns in Power Query or Power BI

value.title: Download PBIX reports - Minute Monday
value.excerpt: In this video, I show you how you can download a PBIX (Power BI Desktop file) from the Power BI service for a given report. Reports have to have been published after November 24. 2016 for the feature to be available. This does work with Live or DirectQuery reports.  Ginger Grant's Blog talking about
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ymWqU5jiUl0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Filter Power BI reports using a URL query string
value.excerpt: In this video, I show you how to filter Power BI reports, within the Power BI service, using a URL query string.  This is actually documented here - https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/powerbi-service-share-unshare-dashboard/#share-just-a-report  In addition to showing you how to filter

value.title: Power BI parameters - Updating in the Power BI Service or with APIs
value.excerpt: In this video, Adam looks at how you can update Power BI parameters within the service or by using APIs. You can create Power BI Parameters within Power BI Desktop using Power Query. Then you can update those Power BI parameters once the report is published to the Power BI service.  PowerShell Samples:
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MJVSu47iMmo" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Power BI Publish to Web can be SCARY!?!
value.excerpt: Some don't realize that Power BI Publish to Web is not secure. Adam shows you that this is the case. It's a bit scary and there are other options to have secure embedding.  Two Alex's Video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S3tWcCcZilw  Patrick's SharePoint video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kevw0PFnFD8

value.title: Setting default values using COALESCE in DAX
value.excerpt: Learn how to get default values using the DAX COALESCE function instead of IF statements. A great way to avoid BLANK in Power BI! value.title: STOP refreshing a single table at a time! (Power BI Desktop)
value.excerpt: Stop refreshing one table at a time! Also, don't wait for the entire data model to finish refreshing. Refresh multiple tables within Power BI Desktop. value.title: How to Show Items with No Data in Power BI (e.g. Show All Month Names)
value.excerpt: Sometimes the default behavior in Power BI can be frustrating. For example, if you are showing month names, you may see that if no data is available then those months may not be shown in your Chart or Table. Often, you would want all months (Jan-Dec) to be shown, regardless of whether data is present

value.title: Power BI DAX Measures: Understanding Filter Context using DATESYTD Example (I.C.A.N. Rule)
value.excerpt: For Power BI DAX Measures, one of the hardest concepts to grasp is the Filter Context. Or is it? I explain the “Filter Context” with the 4-easy-step approach of the I.C.A.N.
